tool.name: tableindex

method.name: tableindex
method.description: Construct an index for the given table. The names of one or more scalar columns forming the index have to be given. If a single name is given, the column can be an array column too. Normally a sort will be done to get the key values in the correct order. If the table is already in the order of the data in the given columns, the argument \texttt{sort} can be set to F to avoid needless sorting.

method.name: set
method.shortdescription: Set table and columns to be indexed
method.description: Reset the \texttt{tableindex} tool to index the given table and columns. It works similar to the tableindex constructor.

param.name: tab
param.description: table to be indexed, wants a table tool

param.name: sort
param.description: is a sort of the key values needed?

method.name: isunique
method.shortdescription: Are all key values in the index unique?
method.description: T is returned if all key values in the index are unique. In that case the function rownr can also be used.

method.name: setchanged
method.shortdescription: Tell the index that columns have changed
method.description: When data are changed in an indexed column, the index should be updated. The tableindex tool recognizes addition and deletion of rows and updates the index accordingly. However, it does not recognize if data in a column are changed. This function can be used to tell the tableindex that data in one or more columns are changed and force it to update the index. If no column names are given it assumes all columns have changed.

method.name: rownr
method.shortdescription: Find the row number matching the search value
method.description: Find the row number (1-relative) of the row containing the given search value. If no row is found, 0 is returned. This function can only be used if the index contains unique key values (thus if isunique returns T), otherwise \texttt{rownrs} should be used. \\Normally the search value should be given as a record in which the field names match the column names in the index. However, if the index is formed from a single column the search value can be given directly as shown in the examples in the introduction. The data type should be correct though.

method.name: rownrs
method.shortdescription: Find the row numbers matching search values
method.description: Find the row numbers of the rows matching the given search value or interval. An interval is given if the \texttt{upperkey} argument is also given. In that case the 3rd and 4th argument determine if the boundaries of the interval are inclusive (i.e. part of the interval). \\As in function \texttt{rownr} the search values must be given as a record if the index consists of multiple columns.

method.name: close
method.description: Close the tableindex. It can thereafter be reused using the set function.

method.name: done
method.description: End the tableindex and free up all memory. It cannot be reused anymore.
